questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that includes Microsoft Intune.

For macOS devices, you create an update policy named Policy1 that has the following settings:

• All other updates (OS, built-in apps): Download and install
• Assignments:
• Included groups: All Devices

Which two types of updates can be downloaded and installed by using Policy1? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
not quite sure but according to MS Learn shouldn't it be macOS and built-in app? 
Critical is a separate option

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/software-updates-macos#:~:text=Configuration%20file%20update-,All%20other%20updates%20(OS%2C%20built%2Din%20apps),-Specify%20a%20schedule

Selected Answer: BE
the answer is in the question, good grief.

Selected Answer: B
i want this in the exam

Selected Answer: BE
macOS Update Policy has these options:
1. Critical
2. Firmware
3. Configuration Files
4. All Other Updated (OS, built in apps)

Hopefully now you know why BE are correct answers.

Selected Answer: BE
A resposta esta na pergunta

Answer should be CD

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/software-updates-macos

Selected Answer: BE
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/software-updates-macos
Check screenshot in configure policy section, critical is it's own category. Answer is literally in the question for this (OS, Built-in apps).

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that includes Microsoft Intune. The subscription contains a group named Group1. Group1 contains devices enrolled in Intune.

You deploy Remote Help in Intune.

You need to configure Remote Help to only allow support administrators to join Remote Help sessions from the devices in Group1.

Which type of Microsoft Entra object should you create, and which type of policy should you configure? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
The security principal defines the access policy and permissions for the user/application in the Microsoft Entra tenant. This enables core features such as authentication of the user/application during sign-in, and authorization during resource access.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity-platform/app-objects-and-service-principals?tabs=browser

My take:
An enterprise application
Conditional Access

When you enable Remote Help in Intune, an Enterprise Application for Remote Help is automatically present in your tenant and if you you want to restrict or control access to Remote Help (e.g., only allow certain admins from certain devices), you configure a Conditional Access policy that targets the Remote Help enterprise application.

Answers look correct
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/remote-help-windows#create-the-service-principal

entra object: service principal
Policy: conditional access
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/remote-help-windows#setup-conditional-access-for-remote-help
 
I had to study that to understand... Remote Help is not a standard app, so you can't find it in Conditional Access without creating a service principal. It's some kind of link to a non-standard app in your AzureAD. I hope I'm not mistaken.
Answer seems to be correct - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/remote-help-windows#create-the-service-principal

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity-platform/howto-create-service-principal-portal
You need to register an app in order to setup a service principal but I believe the answer to be correct as the criteria won't be fulfilled until you enable role based access with the service principal.
Conditional access seems correct too

choices.C: Assign Admin1 the Cloud PC Administrator role.
choices.D: Create a custom Microsoft Entra role and assign the role to Admin1.
choices.E: Create a custom Intune role and assign the role to Admin1.
choices.B: Assign Admin1 the Cloud PC Reader role.
choices.A: Assign Admin1 the Help Desk Operator role.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
Chatgpt said C but Deepseek said E its said its not C bcoz, Cloud PC Administrator Role: While this role allows managing Cloud PC provisioning policies, it does not cover the permissions needed for creating and assigning apps and policies in Intune.

Selected Answer: C
The Cloud PC Administrator role provides the necessary permissions to create, assign, and delete Windows 365 Cloud PC provisioning policies. This role also includes the ability to manage apps and policies in Intune, which covers the requirement to create and assign apps and policies to users and devices.
By assigning this built-in role, you minimize administrative effort as you don't need to create a custom role. The Cloud PC Administrator role follows the principle of least privilege by granting only the permissions needed for Admin1's specific tasks without providing unnecessary access to other areas of the system.

Selected Answer: D
I was wonder whether it's D

sound like we can tailor-made the permissions to Admin1 needs to perform those tasks, without granting excessive access....

Selected Answer: C
Should be C in my opinion. 
E would be ideal and the best way but the question states that it should minimize admin effort. Creating a custom role does not fulfill that requirement. In that case we can also remove D.

That leaves A / B / C. 
Helpdesk role can assign apps and policies to users but it CAN'T create apps and policies, which is a requirement.
Cloud PC Reader has only read access as the name suggest, can't creat anything.

That leaves Cloud PC Administrator, hence answer should be C.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/role-based-access-control#roles

Selected Answer: C
Custom indeed is a solution but that requires more effort. If you assign the cloud administrator it will cover the required action at thesame time principle of least privilege plus minimize admin effort.

Answer is correct "E". Cloud PC admin doesn't have the capability to assign applications.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-365/enterprise/role-based-access

Selected Answer: E
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/role-based-access-control
None of the built in roles can satisfy both requirements, answer is correct

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that includes Microsoft Intune and contains a user named Admin1.

Admin1 must use the Microsoft Intune admin center to perform the following tasks:

• Create and assign apps and policies to users and devices by using Intune.
• Create, assign, and delete Windows 365 Cloud PC provisioning policies.

You need to assign the required roles to Admin1. The solution must meet the following requirements:

• Follow the principle of least privilege.
• Minimize administrative effort.

What should you do?

You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes Microsoft Intune. The subscription contains Windows 11 devices enrolled in Intune. The subscription contains three groups named Departement1, Department2, and Department3.

You need to deploy Microsoft 365 Apps to the Windows 11 devices. The solution must meet the following requirements:

• Users in Department1 and Department2 must receive the full Microsoft 365 Apps suite, including Microsoft Project and Visio.
• Users in Department3 must receive the full Microsoft 365 Apps suite, including Microsoft Project, but without Visio.
• All other users must receive the full Microsoft 365 Apps suite without Microsoft Project or Visio.

What is the minimum number of deployments you should create?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Correct.

1. M365 apps include Dept 1 and Dept 2
2. M365 apps include Dept 3 
3. M365 apps include all users exclude Dept 1,2,3

Selected Answer: C
Correct

Selected Answer: C
Correct

Selected Answer: C
Answer is correct

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that uses Microsoft Intune.

You configure Intune to send log data to Log Analytics.

You need to review events involving devices that fail to enroll in Intune.

What should you monitor?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is the correcnt vatiant.
Operational Logs show details on users and devices that successfully (or failed) to enroll, and details on noncompliant devices.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/review-logs-using-azure-monitor
Correct me if I'm wrong

Selected Answer: A
Operational logs in Microsoft Intune (sent to Log Analytics) provide details about device enrollment failures, policy assignments, and deployment issues. If a device fails to enroll in Intune, the error messages and reasons for failure will be recorded in these logs.

Selected Answer: A
Given answer is correct. Operational Logs show the devices that failed to enroll.

comments.content: Stop using chatgpt... you guys does not even know what an AI it is.
"You configure Intune to send log data to Log Analytics." That's where the logs are found.

discussion.content: Chat GPT says C
